results.headline: That Was No Elephant, That Was My Wife

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Norbit

results.summary_short: Too many of the gags in the sloppy comedy “Norbit” are lumbering and graceless, more fun to anticipate than to witness.

results.headline: Who’s Afraid of an Artist Who Loved Flowers?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Notes on Marie Menken

results.summary_short: “Notes on Marie Menken” shines a welcome ray of light on a largely forgotten figure in the American avant-garde film scene.

results.headline: Sins Devoured, Hope Restored

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Sin Eater

results.summary_short: “The Last Sin Eater” is religious art for mainstream consumption.

results.headline: How He Arrived at That Acquired Taste

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hannibal Rising

results.summary_short: The new prequel  “Hannibal Rising” provides  a back story that ought to have remained firmly in our imaginations.

results.headline: Madness in Mumbai

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Black Friday

results.summary_short: “Black Friday” is a moving and exhausting work of angry humanism.

results.headline: Before the Wall Fell, a Kafkaesque Nightmare

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of La Decomposition de L'ame

results.summary_short: “The Decomposition of the Soul” tackles the unsettling topic of the East German Stasi in a way that might make your flesh crawl.

results.headline: Here’s a Risky Pickup Line: I’m Obsessed With ‘Annie Hall’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Burning Annie

results.summary_short: The “Annie Hall” homage “Burning Annie” is a thoroughly professional comedy, well paced, attractively photographed and smartly acted.

results.headline: The Recurring Stain Should Be a Tipoff

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Messengers

results.summary_short: With “The Messengers,” the Pang brothers devise scenes so scary that they stain the imagination and never scrub out.

results.headline: A Journalist and Beauty, Working It in Iraq

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Situation

results.summary_short: Set in wartime Iraq, “The Situation” is exploitation cinema of the most narcoleptic kind.

results.headline: Girl Leaves Girl, Meets Boy and Then Meets Boy’s Girl

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Puccini for Beginners

results.summary_short: Snappy repartee with the ring of real conversation is sustained through enough of “Puccini for Beginners” to make it a rarity.

results.headline: Behind the Asphalt Walls, Hopes and Heavy Burdens

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In the Pit

results.summary_short: Literally and existentially down and dirty, “In the Pit” is an absorbing documentary about work and the transformation of men into laborers.

results.headline: Warhol’s Anointed Starlet, Drowning in the Glitterati

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Factory Girl

results.summary_short: “Factory Girl,” a biography of Edie Sedgwick, the most glamorous of Andy Warhol’s so-called superstars, suggests a magazine layout masquerading as a film.

results.headline: Mother, Please, I’d Rather Do It Myself

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Because I Said So

results.summary_short: “Because I Said So” is an exercise in deliberate mediocrity, with chuckles and heartwarming moments distributed as carefully as nuts in a factory-made brownie.

results.headline: A Gambling, Scrambling Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tajja

results.summary_short: Choi Dong Hoon directs a terrific film about the sensual energy and reckless optimism of youth.

results.headline: Courage Through Rhymes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of East of Havana

results.summary_short: “East of Havana” celebrates Cuban rappers who tell the truth in a country that muzzles free speech.

results.headline: Losing  a Job, Making a Film

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fired!

results.summary_short: The documentary “Fired!" contains slivers of shtick that play more as diverting filler than prime comedy material.

results.headline: The Aftershocks of Racist Violence

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Constellation

results.summary_short: If earnestness equaled skill, “Constellation” would be a classic.

results.headline: A Hotel Room With Views of 5 Couples’ Relationships

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Room 314

results.summary_short: “Room 314” cracks open the door of an anonymous hotel room where, at different times, five couples navigate critical moments in their relationships.

results.headline: The Endlessly Maddening (for Liberals) Case of Ralph Nader

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of An Unreasonable Man

results.summary_short: The documentary “An Unreasonable Man”  is an admiring but hardly uncritical portrait of Ralph Nader and his 2000 presidential campaign.

results.headline: Bravely Setting Out to Mock Others

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Epic Movie

results.summary_short: Thankfully, the crude, scatological parody “Epic Movie,” unlike the movies it sends up, is short.
